Award.AwardTitle: CC* Network Design: Network Infrastructure to Support Computational Biology, Computational Science, and Computing Across the Curriculum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research partnership of Colby College, the University of Maine, and the Jackson Laboratory are building a dedicated research network to support projects in computational biology, computational physics and astrophysics, computational chemistry, and machine learning, The network is also expanding the capabilities available to faculty in the classroom, enabling more complex and modern classroom and laboratory activities.

The project provides 10Gb network connectivity to all academic buildings at Colby College to give all faculty access to state-of-the-art computing and data facilities, which is critical given the trends in all academic disciplines towards greater use of digital and computing resources. The project also creates a secure dedicated 10Gb research network connecting the Advanced Computing Group resources at the University of Maine and the large genomic databases at the Jackson Laboratory with researchers in variety of disciplines at Colby College.

The new research network provides the capability for researchers at Colby to obtain fast access to gigabyte and terabyte scale data sets from Jackson Laboratory or other sources and make use of advanced computing resources at the University of Maine with a high bandwidth and high availability connection. Using this infrastructure, researchers are able to execute analyses and simulations, and professors are able to assign projects and exercises in courses, that were not previously possible with the old infrastructure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project was to enhance research and teaching in Computational Biology and related areas in the state of Maine by building a dedicated high speed research network connecting Colby College, the University of Maine, and Jackson Laboratories. These three institutions are leaders in Computational Biology within the state, and existing collaborations and teaching activities motivated the need for better connectivity to provide access to data and computational resources.


The project upgraded the entire campus network of Colby College to a high-bandwidth (> 10Gb) infrastructure. It also connected Colby College to the Maine Research Network [MEREN] and set up a dedicated research network connecting Colby, the University of Maine's Advanced Computing Group, and Jackson Laboratories in Bar Harbor. The dedicated research network allowed high speed transfer of data and the sharing of computing resources between the three institutions.


The broader impact of this project was to enable collaboration and teaching activities that involve real-time high performance computing and access to large data sets. As an example, students taking a Biomedical genomics course in a Colby computer lab can access computational facilities at the University of Maine to analyze large genomics data sets from Jackson Laboratories and complete the activities in an afternoon lab session. These types of learning activities were not possible prior to the creation of the dedicated network.


The network also facilitates research, teaching, and collaborations in many other areas such as computer vision, machine learning, astrophysics, and systems biology being undertaken by Colby faculty and students.


The grant also, inadvertently, enabled Colby College to fully support remote learning for its students during the spring of 2020 and has facilitated continuing remote interactions during the COVID-19 pandemic.


The pandemic has brought about a significant change in how faculty and students are working in both their courses and their research. Much of what faculty and students now consider standard capabilities--remote access to data and compute resources, and video-conferencing capabilities in classrooms and labs--would not have been feasible under the old network hardware. The grant has thus had secondary and tertiary benefits for the entire Colby community, not just specific high-bandwidth projects.  In a very real sense, everyone is now a high-end network user and the new network infrastructure enabled Colby to continue to provide an excellent education to its students.
